Award.AwardTitle: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Phylogenetic analysis of vision loss and gene expression in cave and surface adapted crayfish
Award.AbstractNarration:
The repeated loss of pigmentation, eyes and vision in cave-dwelling animals presents biologists with an excellent opportunity to understand the genetic changes that have resulted in the convergent evolution of similar morphological changes in unrelated organisms. Freshwater crayfish have evolved to live in caves on at least seven occasions throughout their history, repeatedly losing vision. This project will use a well-supported evolutionary framework of freshwater crayfish to understand the role of gene regulation in producing iconic cave morphologies. This research will promote training of undergraduate and high school students in field, laboratory, and computational work. Data and analysis pipelines will be made available to the public and will contribute to invertebrate genomics research efforts. Ultimately, this research will advance our knowledge of how organisms adapt to novel habitats and contribute to the growing body of research in vision genomics.

While the genetics of vision loss has been studied in single species systems such as the Mexican blind cave fish (Astyanax mexicanus), comparative studies across multiple species aimed at revealing statistically significant and biologically meaningful correlations have been lacking. The multiple transitions to cave habitats by freshwater crayfish and the subsequent loss of vision in each case make the group an ideal model to test hypotheses concerning the loss of complex traits in response to a common selective pressure. These evolutionarily independent replicates provide statistical power as well as the potential to uncover biologically meaningful correlations. Researchers will use comparative transcriptomics to develop a set of candidate genes related to vision loss and cave adaptation in this system. Gene expression levels will be measured across a set of these genes from multiple individuals of 14 species, both cave and surface, and modeled as an evolving trait on the phylogeny. These data and methods will be used to test if regulatory changes associated with vision loss show a signature of adaptive evolution and if the transcriptome evolves in a predictable way in vision loss events. This project will help to elucidate the role of gene regulation in producing these iconic cave phenotypes, using a unique framework, new technologies, and newly developed evolutionary models.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A striking example of trait loss in nature is the tendency for cave-dwelling animals, living in complete darkness, to evolve reduced visual systems and pigmentation. Over many generations, these animals often lose their eyesight completely and are left with vestigial, non-functional eyes. This is an excellent opportunity to probe the patterns and processes involved in repeated trait loss as well as the genetic underpinnings of vision. In this project we studied freshwater crayfish species, some of the most charismatic members of cave communities, to study the role of gene regulation underlying vision loss in cave animals. Different crayfish lineages have evolved to live in caves at different timepoints, repeatedly evolving reduced eyes and losing vision in the absence of light.

 

This research revealed several novel aspects to the evolution of vision loss in cave animals. Gene expression patterns in the eyes of distantly related cave animals were found to be more similar to each other than to closely related species living on the surface. This similarity was found to be due to similar increases in the rate of gene expression evolution, resulting in increased expression variance within and among species. This suggested that, in the absence of selection maintaining functional eyes in the dark, mutations disrupting gene expression levels can accumulate without negative functional consequences.

 

We also found that cave-adapted animals express a complete repertoire of genes necessary for visual phototransduction. A small number of genes with functions related to phototransduction and eye development were found to be commonly, and possibly adaptively, downregulated in the eyes of different cave species. Analyses of molecular gene sequences revealed a combination of different evolutionary processes and variable signatures of natural selection.

 

Our findings have been disseminated in multiple scientific conferences as well as a public symposium about biological conservation on a changing planet. Data and analysis pipelines have been shared in public databases in order to fuel future research in gene expression evolution, cave adaptation and vision genomics. Hopefully this work will bring attention to the importance of conserving rare and enigmatic cave-dwelling organisms that can provide unique insight into the mechanisms of evolution and the genetics of vision.
